https://prez.dev/description.@value: The coordinate reference systems (geographic and projected) used and referred to within Western Australia. It includes historical and current reference systems, Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zones, and, where applicable, notations based on the EPSG registry (https://epsg.io/). Some concepts are included to account for legacy data/maps with limited information.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A local grid is a locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary, fixed point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted, instead of using a national or global datum.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Local grids are routinely used in mineral exploration, e.g. when establishing drilling or surface sampling lines. Many legacy maps submitted in legacy exploration reports use local grids (with or without the coordinates of the reference point). It is considered this may be a useful concept for when individual maps may be able to be retrieved from WAMEX.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A local grid is a locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary, fixed point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted, instead of using a national or global datum.

Locally defined coordinate reference systems, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are known.

Locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are not known.
